coredata.dc:title: Interphase formation and degradation of charge transfer kinetics between a lithium metal anode and highly crystalline Li7P3S11 solid electrolyte
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
coredata.dc:creator: Wenzel, Sebastian
Weber, Dominik A.
Leichtweiss, Thomas
Busche, Martin R.
Sann, Joachim
Janek, Jürgen
coredata.dc:description: The properties of the interface between solid electrolytes and electrode materials are of vital importance for the performance of all solid-state batteries (ASSB). Unwanted reactions between alkali metal electrodes and the solid electrolyte can lead to the formation of compounds that either facilitate or block the ion transfer kinetics. In particular for lithium solid electrolytes in the Li2S–P2S5 system with very high lithium ion conductivity only little is known about interfacial reactions with lithium metal. Here we monitor the formation of an interphase between Li7P3S11 and lithium metal by a combined analytical approach, comprising in situ photoelectron spectroscopy and time-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Utilizing a self-developed XPS peak fit model for Li7P3S11, we identify the components of this interphase, discuss its properties and develop a qualitative model, which shows that the reaction between electrolyte and lithium metal, and hence, the interphase growth, is limited to a few nm. The solid electrolyte being used is a highly crystalline form of the superionic conductor Li7P3S11 without any residual glassy phase, and the synthesis of this Li7P3S11 phase is also reported.

Schmidt (BELLA Laboratory at INT, Karlsruhe) for helpful discussions and scientific support. Fruitful discussion within the BASF Scientific Network for Electrochemistry and Batteries is highly appreciated. Appendix A

ce:caption.ce:simple-para:
Crystal structure of triclinic Li7P3S11 with PS4 tetrahedra (light green) and P2S7 di-tetrahedra (dark green); view along [ 0
1 -
0 ]; gray dashed lines represent correlations in the network of neighboring Li+ cations.

Comparison of the diffraction diagrams (routine measurements under polyimide foil, Bragg–Brentano geometry) of an amorphous sample (red), a sample with low crystallinity (green) and a highly crystalline sample (black); the strongly structured background can be ascribed to the polyimide foil; for better differentiation, an offset to the intensity has been applied.

X-ray powder diffraction diagram (measured in Debye–Scherrer geometry in sealed glass capillaries) of a mixture of 12.4mg (81.58 wt.-%) phase-pure Li7P3S11 and 2.8mg (18.42 wt.-%) LaB6 with graphical results of the Rietveld refinement; numerical results (cf. Table 1) point to a crystalline fraction of 100% in Li7P3S11; theoretical positions of the Bragg reflections for Li7P3S11 (blue) and LaB6 (red) are depicted by vertical lines.

Arrhenius plots of the electrical conductivity for an amorphous, a partially crystalline and two fully crystalline samples of Li7P3S11, of which one was cold pressed and one was densified as described in the text. Iso-conductivity lines were drawn dotted gray and the room temperature is marked as RT.
Photoelectron spectra of diphosphorus pentasulfide showing the fitted S 2p and P 2p signals. The inset shows the molecular structure of the compound.
XPS detail spectra of the Li7P3S11 ceramic for the S 2p and P 2p signals. The peak model is based on structural information.

A sample pellet was mechanically contacted using two (mechanically) cleaned lithium electrodes and analyzed by time-dependent impedance spectroscopy. In (a) Nyquist plots for the freshly contacted sample and after 12h and the fit model are shown as well as the equivalent circuit. The charge transfer (CT) and the high frequency data points were removed for the fit. The overall, solid electrolyte and SEI resistance changes are summarized in (b).

Waterfall plots for the S 2p and P 2p signals for the lithium deposition steps. Likewise, the Li 1s signal is shown for an as-received and one deposited sample; the formation of a lithium metal film is notable.
XPS detail spectra of the as received sample (Fig. 6) and for the S 2p and P 2p signals after 80min of deposition (16 deposition cycles) and the peak model of the Li7P3S11 ceramic after reaction.
Relative molar fractions of sulfur (a) and phosphorus species (b) for different deposition times.
Waterfall plot for the P 2p, S 2p and O 1s signals and potential changes after lithium deposition on Li7P3S11.
Waterfall plots of the S 2p, P 2p, O 1s and Li 1s signals during depth profiling. Sputtering steps of 2min duration and a beam energy of 2keV were used.
Theoretical growth rate of the SEI as function of the SEI thickness d SEI in the range of 0.1 to 50nm for different electronic conductivities of Li2S.
Numerical results of the Rietveld refinement of the Li7P3S11–LaB6 mixture.

XPS fitting parameters for Li7P3S11. A Gaussian–Lorentzian line shape (GL(30)) was used. All detail spectra were fitted using Shirley background correction. The 2p3/2 and the 2p1/2 area ratio was fixed to 0.5 according to the ratio of degeneracy, the FWHM values were constrained between 0.8eV for P 2p and 2eV for S 2p and were set to be equal for the corresponding 2p3/2 and the 2p1/2 peaks.

head.ce:title: Interphase formation and degradation of charge transfer kinetics between a lithium metal anode and highly crystalline Li7P3S11 solid electrolyte

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Physikalisch Chemisches Institut, Justus-Liebig-Universität Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 17, 35392 Giessen, Germany

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The properties of the interface between solid electrolytes and electrode materials are of vital importance for the performance of all solid-state batteries (ASSB). Unwanted reactions between alkali metal electrodes and the solid electrolyte can lead to the formation of compounds that either facilitate or block the ion transfer kinetics. In particular for lithium solid electrolytes in the Li2S–P2S5 system with very high lithium ion conductivity only little is known about interfacial reactions with lithium metal. Here we monitor the formation of an interphase between Li7P3S11 and lithium metal by a combined analytical approach, comprising in situ photoelectron spectroscopy and time-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Utilizing a self-developed XPS peak fit model for Li7P3S11, we identify the components of this interphase, discuss its properties and develop a qualitative model, which shows that the reaction between electrolyte and lithium metal, and hence, the interphase growth, is limited to a few nm. The solid electrolyte being used is a highly crystalline form of the superionic conductor Li7P3S11 without any residual glassy phase, and the synthesis of this Li7P3S11 phase is also reported.

ce:section.ce:para: Rechargeable lithium ion batteries (LIB) with a liquid (non-aqueous) electrolyte have become the most important battery type and dominate electrochemical energy storage applications. Further improvement of the energy density mostly relies on the optimization of existing storage phases and of processing technologies. A jump in energy density might be possible if the lithium metal anode could be utilized – irrespective of the type of cathode. While this is considered to be extremely difficult in liquid electrolytes, as dendrites easily form during charging, there is some hope that solid electrolytes enable the use of a metal anode. Ceramic or glassy electrolytes may overcome safety issues and parasitic effects known for cells using liquid electrolytes [1] and therefore attract new interest as components of all-solid state batteries (ASSB, or SSLB for “solid state lithium batteries”), recently [2]. Most known lithium solid electrolytes show lower lithium ion conductivity than advanced liquid electrolytes, and therefore, new types of solid electrolytes are explored and investigated. Meanwhile these new electrolytes show highly promising conductivities which are comparable to or even greater than those observed in liquid electrolytes [3]. But as in the case of liquid electrolytes, the compatibility with typical electrode materials will be critical for any battery application – and in the case of solid electrolytes the compatibility with lithium metal is of primary interest. Therefore we explore the compatibility of one of the best lithium solid electrolytes with lithium metal.

In the last few years, the interest in sulfur-containing solid lithium ion conductors has grown steadily [4], ranging from argyrodite [5–7] and LGPS (Li10GeP2S12) analogs [8–14] to Li2S–P2S5 compounds. Sodium analogs are investigated in parallel, but often show surprisingly different properties [15]. Recently, different compounds with high ionic conductivities in the order of 10mS/cm were reported for the quasi-binary system Li2S–P2S5 (in the following denoted as LPS phases) [3,16]. Different synthesis methods [17–19] (ball milling or high temperature precipitation), resulting in similar electrochemical properties, and substitutions (e. g. P2O5) to increase the conductivity [16] and to prevent H2S gas formation [20], were described. Thin films prepared by PLD (at room temperature) show relatively low conductivities of around 8×10−5 S/cm [21]. Typically, a crystallization step is following the synthesis of glassy compounds, yielding glass-ceramic materials with high conductivity. For this step, different temperatures, annealing times and procedures (e. g. hot pressing) were reported [3,17,18]. Precedent glass formation is a useful way to obtain high temperature phases like the metastable Li7P3S11 at room temperature. The degree of crystallinity and the formation of side products then strongly influence the conductivity [18]. Among the different LPS materials, glass ceramics with the composition 70 Li2S–30 P2S5 (Li7P3S11) show the highest conductivity of up to 17mS/cm which can be obtained for hot-pressed samples [3]. Li7P3S11 crystallizes triclinic in the space group P
1 -
(Fig. 1 ) and reveals a quick and extremely complex translational movement of lithium ions along zigzag chains in the open space between P2S7 di-tetrahedra and slightly distorted PS4 tetrahedra [22]. Recent investigations on these materials as solid electrolytes in bulk-type all solid-state batteries show that the contact between electrodes and solid electrolyte sensitively depends on the particle size of the material [23,24]. Due to their good ductility at room temperature sulfide-based glass-ceramics can easily be contacted with the electrodes, and the grain-boundary resistance depends strongly on the processing. We attribute the wide range of reported conductivities between 1mS/cm and 17mS/cm to grain boundary effects [4].

Sulfide glasses in the system Li2S–P2S5 not only show promising electrochemical properties but are also reported to be stable in contact with lithium metal [25]. In contrast to these reports, the overpotential of lithium electrodes in contact with Li2S–P2S5 glass ceramics (Li3PS4) is found to be slightly higher in the first cycle than in the following cycles, and a stable and reproducible overpotential is only observed after three cycles [26]. The authors assumed that an unknown kind of passivation layer had formed.

Techniques to investigate the formation of interphases at solid/solid electrodes and the interphases themselves are rarely reported [12,27,28]. This can be mainly attributed to the buried nature of the interphase and its limited thickness, which causes serious difficulties to obtain reliable analyses – in particular if high resolution transmission electron microscopy causes too much beam damage. Irrespective of their thickness, the formation of interphases and the interphase properties can have great influence on the kinetics of the corresponding interface. LiPON, just to name one example, was believed to be stable in contact with lithium metal – but actually reacts with lithium metal to lithium oxide, lithium nitride and lithium phosphide [27]. Thus, the physical and chemical properties of the interface are completely altered, modifying the functionality and the rate capability of the Li/LIPON interface and probably facilitating the Li electrode in thin film batteries. Mostly, the stability of solid electrolytes in contact with lithium metal is investigated phenomenologically by cyclic voltammetry (CV) or electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), two methods which allow to monitor interphase formation in situ but do not provide chemical information [12]. Combining impedance spectroscopy with in situ photoelectron spectroscopy allows the chemical identification of reaction products and gives information about the type of interphase [28].

As summarized in a previous paper, three different types of interfaces can be distinguished in the case of Li/Li solid electrolyte contacts [28]: A two-dimensional (thermodynamically) stable interface, a mixed conducting growing interphase (MCI) [29] and a stable (non-growing) interphase (SEI) in the case of a thermodynamically unstable interface [28]. These three types influence the charge transfer kinetics quite differently. The MCI alters the properties of the bulk material and leads to short circuit and failure of the cell, whereas the stable interface – where both materials are a priori in thermodynamic equilibrium – shows no effect. Against this, the SEI (non-growing interphase) may show two different effects, which are strongly dependent on the nature and especially the transport properties of the reaction products, which is discussed later. To prevent the degradation of the charge transfer kinetics, the introduction of protecting films (“artificial SEI”) has been repeatedly reported [30–33].

The main goal of this paper is to clarify whether sulfidic (glass-) ceramics are stable in contact with lithium metal and which products are formed at the interface. We study Li7P3S11 as a model case, and we quantify the crystallinity of Li7P3S11 by detailed XRD measurements (see below). The stability of Li7P3S11 in contact with lithium metal is investigated using an in situ photoelectron spectroscopy approach [28]. Photoelectron reference spectra of Li7P3S11 at low temperatures are reported and a peak fit model is derived, allowing precise analysis of the formed interphase at the Li/Li7P3S11 interface. The aging of the Li/Li7P3S11 interface is also monitored by impedance spectroscopy, and the results are compared with results from in situ XPS. A quantitative interphase model is developed that combines the conclusions from both photoelectron and impedance spectroscopy measurements.

All materials were handled in an argon filled glove box (MBraun). Li7P3S11 was synthesized using stoichiometric amounts of Li2S (Sigma Aldrich, 99.98%) and P2S5 (Sigma Aldrich, 99%). The mixture was ball-milled in a Pulverisette 7 Premium Line (Fritsch) under argon atmosphere for 144h (overall milling time) at 510rpm using a ZrO2 grinding bowl of 80mL volume and ZrO2 balls with a diameter of 3mm. One milling cycle consisted of 10min milling and 20min cooling to prevent sulfur evaporation. To gain better homogeneity, the agglomerated powder was intermittently ground with an agate mortar every 8h of milling time. After complete amorphization of the material, one additional milling step was carried out to make sure that the reaction to the 70 Li2S–30 P2S5 (mol.-%) glass was completed. The glass was then crystallized in a PTFE-sealed borosilicate glass jar using a gas-tight steel vessel. Crystallization temperature was set to 250°C for 24h, followed by an additional temperature step at 260°C for 30min in a Nabertherm (L 5/13/P330) furnace. Temperature was additionally controlled by an external thermocouple. The crystallized product was then pelletized isostatically at 4000bar and sintered for 12h at 250°C. Thermodynamic data were calculated using the database HSC Chemistry 7.00 (Outotec Research). Data for Li7P3S11 were not available and substituted by reference materials (e. g. P4S10). Structural investigations and determination of the crystalline fraction in the samples were carried out by means of X-ray powder diffraction. Routine measurements, allowing for first comparison of samples, were done using stainless steel sample holders which were sealed with an adhesive polyimide foil in the argon atmosphere of the glove box. Measurements of these samples were carried out on a PANalytical Empyrean powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ1 =154.056pm, λ2 =154.539pm, I(λ2/λ1)=0.5) in Bragg–Brentano θ–θ geometry, using a PIXcel detector with 255 measuring channels. Diffraction diagrams were recorded in a 2θ range of 10° to 90° with a step size of 0.026° and a counting time of 270s per step. Measurements intended for structural refinement were carried out on a STOE Stadi-P diffractometer in Debye–Scherrer geometry, applying monochromatic Cu Kα1 radiation (λ=154.056pm) and a Mythen2 R 1K detector with 1280 strips. Samples were sealed under argon in borosilicate glass capillaries and diffraction patterns were recorded in a 2θ range of 10° to 80° with a step size of 0.012° and a counting time of 780s per step. For the determination of the crystalline fraction, samples were thoroughly mixed with small amounts of LaB6 (NIST Standard Reference Material 660B) as internal standard. More information will be given in the Results and discussion section. The program package FullProf Suite (version January 2015) [34] was used for structural refinements. Peak profiles were fitted with a pseudo Voigt function and the background was described by linear interpolation between a set of manual points with refinable heights.

Cells for conductivity measurements were built as sealed pouch cells with vapor-deposited Au electrodes. Impedance measurements were performed using a sp300 impedance analyzer (Biologic) in a frequency range of 7MHz to 100mHz in a climate chamber enabling measurements in a temperature range of −40°C to 60°C. Potential amplitude was 20mV. Likewise, stability was investigated using time-resolved impedance spectroscopy inside an argon filled glove box. Therefore, a lithium foil (Rockwood lithium) was mechanically surface-cleaned and directly pressed onto the solid ion conductor. The partial electronic conductivity was measured via a polarization method, using ion blocking electrodes (Au) and applying a potential of 1V.

XPS measurements were carried out using a PHI Versaprobe II Scanning ESCA Microprobe (Physical Electronics). A monochromatized Al Kα X-ray source (Beam diameter 200μm, X-ray power of 50W) was used. Depth profiling and lithium deposition were carried out using the built-in argon ion gun, as described previously [28]. Sample transfer to the XPS machine and handling were performed under inert gas atmosphere (Ar). The pass energy of the analyzer was set to 49.5eV for in situ, time-dependent (waiting) and depth profiling measurements and to 23.5eV for the measurements of the pristine sample. During measurement all samples were cooled to temperatures between −80°C and −90°C to prevent sulfur sublimation. Lithium deposition and data acquisition time were 5min and 25min per deposition step, respectively. Further information on the experimental details was reported previously [28]. The chamber pressure was in the range of 10−7 Pa during the measurements.

Spectral data were evaluated using the CasaXPS software package [35]. Charge correction was carried out relative to the adventitious carbon signal (284.8eV). Coupled XPS peak model fitting was conducted. In short, areas of the respective O 1s, S 2p and P 2p components for Li2O, Li2S and Li3P were coupled to the areas of the corresponding components of the Li 1s signals. The amount of lithium metal and lithium oxide – the latter being a side reaction product – can be distinguished from the SEI species.

Directly after preparation, routine XRD measurements were carried out to gather first information on the purity and crystallinity of the prepared materials. Three diffraction diagrams of samples at different states of crystallization are presented in Fig. 2 . As expected, the XRD of the 70 Li2S–30 P2S5 glass (red), due to its amorphous nature, reveals a halo pattern. After 12h of heat treatment at 250°C, broad, weak and poorly differentiated reflections of the desired crystalline phase, Li7P3S11, were found (green).

At this state, the sample showed typical characteristics of a glass-ceramic, as it is often described in the literature [18]. The diffraction pattern of the sample that was treated as described in the experimental section (black), presents sharp and significantly stronger reflections of Li7P3S11 that are distinct and well distinguishable. This sample was phase pure and did not contain any residual amorphous fraction, as will be shown in the following.

Graphical and numerical results of the Rietveld refinement of a measurement in Debye–Scherrer geometry are shown in Fig. S1 and Tables S1 and S2. It is worth mentioning that for this sample even with a simple laboratory XRD setup, an excellent differentiation between reflections is possible, resembling results of far more elaborate synchrotron measurements [37].

The difference curve as well as the low residual values with a goodness of fit of S =1.05 is indicative for a good agreement between measured data and the theoretical structural model. Consideration of the typically found side phase Li4P2S6 or the starting materials in the structural model did not lead to any further improvement of the residual values, proving that the prepared material is phase pure within the error margins of XRD.

In order to gain information on the crystalline fraction, 12.4mg (81.58 wt.-%) of the sample was mixed with 2.8mg (18.42 wt.-%) LaB6 and thoroughly ground before being measured in Debye–Scherrer geometry. As the crystalline standard LaB6 does not present any amorphous fraction, its well-defined scattering fully contributes to the measured diffraction diagram. Amorphous fractions in the prepared Li7P3S11 sample, on the other hand, do not contribute to the diagram and will therefore be identified as deviation from the weighed masses by Rietveld refinement [38]. The graphical and numerical results of the refinement are shown in Fig. 3 and Tables 1 and S3. Please note that due to the higher symmetry, the scattering intensity of the cubic LaB6 is far more concentrated to a few reflections (10 reflections within the measured range vs. 1217 reflections for triclinic Li7P3S11), leading to considerably higher intensities for this compound, even though only a small amount is present. From the difference curve and the low residuals with a goodness of fit of S =1.27, again, a good agreement of the theoretical crystallographic model with the measured data is found. The refined phase fractions of 83(2) wt.-% for Li7P3S11 and 16.6(3) wt.-% for LaB6 are close to the weighed ones, and, taking into account the experimental error occurring during mortaring of the small amounts of powder inside the glove box, point to a fully crystalline Li7P3S11 sample. Hence, for further analyses, the material is considered to be phase pure and 100% crystalline.

The Arrhenius plots of the electrical conductivity of four differently treated samples are shown in Fig. 4 . The amorphous glass shows an activation energy of 381±4meV (36.8±0.4kJ/mol) and a conductivity of 0.05mS/cm at room temperature. By partial crystallization, the activation energy is slightly increased to 401±3meV (38.7±0.3kJ/mol) and the room temperature conductivity triples to 0.15mS/cm. Using the new crystallization approach, crystallinities of 100% were achieved, leading to activation energies of 396±2meV (38.2±0.2kJ/mol) and a room temperature conductivity of 2mS/cm. The high activation energy and the relatively low conductivity – compared to hot pressed samples [3] – are probably caused by grain boundary effects. To verify this result, a pellet was densified (sintered) for 12h at 250°C. The pellet prepared in that way showed an activation energy of 289±5meV (27.9±0.5kJ/mol) and a conductivity of 4mS/cm at room temperature. Thus, the activation energy could be decreased by more than 100meV and the conductivity was doubled, giving strong evidence that the grain boundaries greatly influence both the activation energy and conductivity.

The electronic partial conductivity of solid electrolytes is usually determined by a Wagner–Hebb experiment, which strictly requires one lithium electrode (and an inert second electrode). Being aware of the fact that lithium may change the properties of the material at the interface, we used a polarization cell with two identical blocking electrodes (vide supra). This technique yielded a value of 8nS/cm for the electronic partial conductivity of Li7P3S11, which is comparable to the values reported for LGPS [10]. It is approximately six orders of magnitude smaller than the value of the ionic conductivity, qualifying this material as electrolyte in all-solid-state batteries.

To develop a fit model for the Li7P3S11 photoelectron spectra, a reference material – P2S5 (Sigma Aldrich, 99%) – was analyzed and compared to its molecular structure. In Fig. 5 the XPS detail spectrum of P2S5 (more accurate: P4S10) is shown. The pelletized sample was cooled to temperature of about −80°C to −90°C during exposure to UHV to avoid sulfur evaporation. The P 2p detail spectrum shows one doublet signal which we attribute to a single phosphorus species in the sample. The binding energy value is 134eV and the splitting is 1.5eV.

P4S10 has a molecular structure that is very similar to the structure of P4O10 [39] (XPS spectra of P2O5 are shown in Fig. S2). Consequently, the S 2p signal can be described by two doublet lines at around 164.9eV and 163.3eV respectively, corresponding to the different sulfur species. We obtain an area ratio of 58% to 42%. Due to the theoretical and measured ratios, we assume that the signal at higher binding energies corresponds to bridging sulfur. Using these reference data, we develop a peak model for Li7P3S11 (70 Li2S–30 P2S5) in the following section.

In a first step, the sulfur content of a sample that was cooled during the XPS measurement was compared (quantified) with that of an uncooled sample. While the cooled sample showed compositions close to the theoretical values, the uncooled sample revealed a conspicuously smaller sulfur content. This implies that cooling during the measurement is necessary for this type of compound – otherwise erroneous analyses are obtained. As a first result, the cooled sample showed no changes in composition within 12h in UHV. Quantification and the error of the cooled sample were obtained via CasaXPS and roughly result in an atomic composition of ca. 33±1.2% lithium, 14±0.3% phosphorus and 53±0.9% sulfur (error is lower than 1.3%), which approximately meets the theoretical values (Li: 33.3%; P: 14.3%; S: 52.4%).

Based on the results in Section 3.2, a peak model for Li7P3S11 is described in the following. Fig. 6 shows fitted spectra for the S 2p and P 2p signals of a pelletized sample. The fit parameters are summarized in Table 2 . Generally, the widths of the peaks for different species are very small (around 1eV), which seems to be characteristic for the material.

The S 2p signal in Fig. 6 can be described by three different sulfur species. A closer look at the structural model of Li7P3S11 reveals (see Fig. 1) that the PS4 3− and P2S7 4− units contain three different sulfur species: one bridging (P―S―P), three double bound (PS) and seven P―S―Li sulfur atoms. According to the spectra of the reference material (see Section 3.2), we attribute the signal at the highest binding energy (163eV) to bridging sulfur and the peak at 162.1eV to double bound sulfur. The S 2p signal at 161.5eV then stems from the P―S―Li group. Comparison of the peak areas yields a ratio of approximately 1:3:7 of the P―S―P, the PS and the P―S―Li sulfur species, respectively, fitting well with the theoretical values for Li7P3S11.

The P 2p signal in Fig. 6 can be described by two species corresponding to P2S7 4− and PS4 3 − species. Here, the ratio for the two compounds again fits well to the theoretical ratio. Thus, for the elements phosphorus and sulfur in Li7P3S11 a consistent fitting model for Li7P3S11 could be developed, which allows for the investigation of interfacial effects, reactions and changes in stoichiometry as will be shown in the following. Due to the small photoionization cross-section of lithium, the Li 1s signal at a binding energy of approximately 55.5eV (not shown) was not included in the fits.

In contact with lithium metal, lithium ion conductors can form three different types of interphases/interfaces: a thermodynamically stable (sharp) interface, a mixed conducting and reactive (growing) interphase (mixed conducting interphase, MCI) and a reactive but kinetically stabilized interphase with electron- and/or ion-blocking properties (SEI) [28]. When in contact with lithium metal the total resistance of a mixed conducting interphase may gradually decrease due to the ongoing reduction of the solid electrolyte, leading to an increase of the electronic partial conductivity. In the extreme case, the MCI will grow across the solid electrolyte and will short-circuit the cell. In contrast, the resistance of a kinetically stabilized interphase (SEI) stabilizes after a formation period. This may be due to either very low ionic and/or electronic conductivity of the SEI. Whether the resistance of the interphase increases or decreases, the overall resistance of the solid electrolyte (including the interphases/interfaces) will reflect the interfacial processes. Thus, contacting lithium metal foils to both sides of a solid electrolyte pellet, followed by time-dependent impedance spectroscopy measurements, can give first information on the type of interphase and the formed components. In Fig. 7a, Nyquist plots for the freshly contacted sample and the sample after 12h contact are shown. Fitting these data is difficult as bulk and grain boundary contributions of the impedance were only partly resolved, which is explained by the high conductivity of the sample. Fig. 7a shows an increasing impedance with time, which could be assigned to the formation of an interphase.

Fig. 7b shows the resistance changes of a Li/Li7P3S11/Li-cell with the first 30h. The impedance of the cell stabilizes after about 12h and does not change even after more than 24h. This indicates that the interphase formation reaction is completely finished after about 12h of contact and we assume that a non-growing interphase, i.e. a SEI has formed. Due to the better contact, this reaction can be expected to be even faster for vapor deposited electrodes. As will be shown later, Li2S is the main component of the interphase and, based on this information, a value for the interphase thickness can be estimated. Taking 10nS/cm as ionic conductivity for Li2S [40] and an observed resistance increase of 45Ω (for one electrode), we estimate an interphase thickness of only 2.3nm.

For the in situ photoelectron spectroscopy experiment, the Li7P3S11 sample was cooled to temperatures below −80°C to avoid sublimation of sulfur. Lithium metal was deposited as described previously in this journal [28]. After each lithiation (deposition) step, XPS detail spectra were recorded.

Fig. 8 shows waterfall plots for S 2p and P 2p detail spectra. Please note, that for S 2p a second graph with reversed deposition step axis (z-axis) is shown to emphasize the initial sample state (of the pristine sample) and the formation of Li2S. Before lithium deposition, the sample shows the expected components of the pristine sample. After the first deposition step, Li2S (around 160eV) and Li3P (around 126 to 127eV) have formed [27,41,42]. Upon further lithium deposition the Li7P3S11, Li3P and Li2S signals decrease as the solid electrolyte and the reaction layer (interphase) are buried by a metallic lithium film as shown in Fig. 8 (for the Li 1s signal). It had been previously assumed that LGPS (Li10GeP2S12) forms a Li2S-containing interphase [4,43] (simulations also hint to a reduction of germanium [44]), which matches our observations for Li7P3S11.

Fig. 9 shows the modeled detail spectra for the pristine sample and after deposition of lithium metal for comparison. The fit parameters are summarized in Table S4. Here, the amount of Li2S is higher compared to the sulfur species of the starting material due to damping of the signal for the buried solid electrolyte. This finding will also be discussed later. The model in Fig. 9 shows the formation of Li2S and Li3P. Moreover, two additional doublets – denoted as “reduced phosphorus species” – have to be included in the fit, these might be attributed to polyphosphide compounds such as LiP, LiP5 or LiP7 [45].
In Fig. 10 the relative molar fractions of the different sulfur and phosphorus species are shown. For increasing deposition time, the errors increase due to signal damping.

In case of the sulfur species, an equal amount of the starting material and of Li2S is found after five deposition steps. For the phosphorus components, the relative amount of reduced species increases for the first two deposition steps and decreases afterwards to values of ca. 20%. Li3P is formed during the first four deposition steps and then stays at a constant level of about 25%. Further comments on the reduced phosphorus species and Li3P will be given later. A deposition time of 3600s corresponds to 15nm of deposited lithium metal. Further deposition decreases the signal intensity of the Li7P3S11 starting material so that mainly the interphase is measured. Various effects may lead to small changes of peak shapes, positions and FWHMs during deposition. A system of stacked layers – which forms in this case – with different densities, conductivities and electron escape depths may greatly influence the measurement and data evaluation. Therefore, fitting parameters for the starting material were taken from the initial model and the initial position and FWHMs constraints were loosened to values of ±0.2eV and ±0.1eV, respectively. Thus, error bars are shown in Fig. 10, which show that the error increases for longer deposition times.

In the literature [28] the influence of the reaction kinetics for diffusion (cycle) times of 30min for the in situ experiment is assessed. Unfortunately, the diffusion coefficients for the components of the initial reaction are not reported. Therefore, we only consider the diffusion of ions and electrons through the main component of the interphase, Li2S. Conductivities for electrons [46] and lithium ions [39] in Li2S are reported and diffusion coefficients are estimated using the Nernst–Einstein relation. By comparing both conductivities, the electronic conductivity is smaller compared to the ionic conductivity and electrons therefore represent the minority charge carriers. Assuming a hopping mechanism for electron transport in Li2S, the electron diffusion coefficient can be roughly assessed and is found to be in the order of 10−20 cm2/s at room temperature. The diffusion coefficients at lower temperatures will be even smaller. In view of the kinetic limitations of the in situ photoelectron spectroscopy technique described in [28], the reaction is slow enough and should not proceed during one measurement step. Therefore, the in situ photoelectron spectroscopy measurements result in steady spectra during acquisition time and therefore this technique is suitable for the investigation of interphase formation on Li2S–P2S5 compounds.

The full decomposition reaction of one formula unit Li7P3S11 to Li2S and Li3P requires 24 lithium metal atoms. By consideration of the deposition rate (0.25nm/min) [28] – approximately 15nm of lithium metal is deposited – and the reaction in Eq. (1), a SEI film with a thickness of ca. 17nm could be formed if all lithium would react.

Due to its reactivity the freshly deposited lithium metal not only reacts with the solid electrolyte but also with unavoidable traces of oxygen in the UHV chamber. To evaluate the fraction of lithium metal that reacted either with oxygen or with the sample, coupled XPS peak fitting was carried out, as described by Fiedler et al. and explained in the experimental section. Thereby, the intensity of the Li2O component of the O 1s signal is coupled to the lithium intensity and so forth. The result shows that only 12at.-% of the lithium metal reacted with Li7P3S11 which reduces the film thickness (SEI) to approximately 2nm. Hence, the value calculated from the impedance measurements (2.3nm, vide supra) matches very well with the value obtained by XPS analysis.

The formation of Li3P and Li2S is evident from the results. Cooling during the measurement procedure may lead to thinner interphases than under normal operation at room temperature but we do not expect completely different chemical behavior. In order to decide whether the material reacts in contact with lithium metal or not, we also made some simple thermodynamic calculations. Unfortunately, thermodynamic data for Li7P3S11 and some phosphorus containing compounds are missing in the database. Consequently, P4S10 was used as substitution and data for its reaction with lithium metal were calculated. The reaction of P4S10 to phosphorus (as a substitution for Li3P) and lithium sulfide results in a negative Gibbs free energy of −4047kJ/mol(P4S10) or −202kJ/mol(Li0) at room temperature and −4062kJ/mol(P4S10) or −203kJ/mol(Li0) at −100°C. Thus, the results of the in situ photoelectron spectroscopy investigations are supported by the thermodynamic calculations, proving that also phosphorus species react with lithium metal.

For further investigation of the effect of the cooling process during the reaction, a thin film of lithium metal (approximately 15nm) was vapor deposited ex situ onto a Li7P3S11 sample pellet. This sample was transferred into the XPS machine 4h after deposition, to ensure that the lithium metal had completely reacted with the material. In this measurement, only Li2S and Li2O were found in the interphase, while the phosphorus signal seemed to be unaffected by the reaction. As lithium metal even reacts with small traces of oxygen in glove boxes and UHV chambers, Li2O is well expected as one reaction product. Having the removal of sulfur–phosphorus bonds by Li metal in mind, the absence of reduced phosphorus species and Li3P, on the other hand, is quite surprising, but might be explained by the lack of vacuum stability and reactions with residual oxygen and moisture [45] (inside the XP spectrometer). For clarification of the possible reaction of Li3P, the in situ deposited sample was measured as function of time inside the XP spectrometer.

In Fig. 11 , P 2p, S 2p and O 1s spectra are shown for different waiting times after lithium deposition. The P 2p signal in Fig. 11 shows the most significant changes. Li3P vanishes completely after a few hours. One possible reason is the reaction with trace amounts of oxygen and water in the UHV chamber as the growing O 1s signal at approximately 531.4eV in Fig. 11 may hint to the formation of oxidized phosphorus species.

Due to the ongoing formation of Li2O by the oxidation of the deposited lithium metal, the O 1s signal at 528.5eV increases with time, whereas the signal for lithium metal is diminished (not shown). The S 2p spectrum hardly changes: Components of both species, Li2S and the remaining Li7P3S11 solid electrolyte show a constant ratio, proving that the film (i.e. the solid electrolyte interphase) does not grow in the course of time.

Following the time-dependent measurements, XPS depth profiling was performed (Fig. 12 ). After ca. 12min of ion sputtering the surface layer (i.e. lithium metal and interphase) was completely removed as can be seen by the disappearance of Li2S and Li2O species as well as by the intensity decrease of the lithium signal. As a consequence, signals for all elements of the solid electrolyte (Li7P3S11) increase in intensity until stabilizing at a constant level. It is noteworthy that the signal shape of these species is unaffected by the sputtering process and correlates well with the spectra for the pristine material. These observations strongly support the assumption of the formation of a non-growing interphase (SEI). The small amount of oxygen left in the sample may result from surface contamination of the starting material or small oxygen contents of the material itself.

The growth rate of the SEI can be estimated following the standard approach for a diffusion driven growth of a mixed-conducting phase (Wagner model for tarnishing) [47]. The molar flux j Li of lithium as neutral component across the forming film is described in Eq. (2) by the transport coefficients – represented by the partial conductivities of ions σLi+ and electrons σe- (or the average conductivities)– and the chemical potential gradient of lithium across the film. The gradient is approximated by the difference of the chemical potential ∇μ Li of lithium at the lithium metal electrode and at the front of the film in the electrolyte.

The chemical potential of lithium in the solid electrolyte is not known but – without doubt – is significantly smaller compared to the chemical potential of Li in lithium metal. Thus, the potential difference is approximated as the chemical potential of lithium metal. With the flux, the molar mass M and the density ρ of Li7P3S11 and a reaction ratio (see Eq. (1)) a theoretical growth rate r SEI in dependence of the SEI thickness is calculated using Eq. (3). As we assume the maximal driving force, this rate can be considered as an upper estimate.

Using Eqs. (2) and (3), the theoretical SEI growth rate is calculated and shown in Fig. 13 as function of the SEI thickness. For a SEI thickness of 2nm, a theoretical growth rate of 0.17nm/h is obtained. The growth rate decreases strongly for the first few nanometers and then slowly decreases to values approaching practically zero. Note that our kinetic model grounds on the assumption of a single crystalline solid and the lack of phase transfer barriers and perfect contacts. In essence, the SEI is supposed to grow further, but the growth rate is strongly decreasing, which matches well with our results of a slowly advancing interphase.

Using the increasing SEI resistance (as measured), the SEI growth rate for this cell as function of the measurement time is calculated, which is shown in Fig. 13 in red color. By comparison of both graphs, the decrease of the growth rate shows similar values during the time interval within the first few nanometers in Fig. 13. Thus, both measurement and model agree quite well. Note that the influence of Li3P – which may show high lithium ion conductivity – is not taken into account due to missing data.

The formation of the interphase, the type of interphase (SEI or MCI), and especially the growth rate depend on the diffusion coefficients of the minority charge carriers [28]. For Li2S, the electronic and ionic conductivities are very low. Therefore, its formation deteriorates (increases) the transfer resistance for both, electrons and ions – as shown by time-dependent impedance measurements and discussed above – and strongly influences the performance of the interface – as indicated by our impedance measurements – and thereby of the full cell. These parameters, again, have a strong impact on the durability and function of batteries. The same considerations can be made for the formation of Li3P, as its ionic conductivity is smaller than that of Li7P3S11. Although the growth rate is strongly decreasing with increasing SEI thickness and time, for thin film electrolytes, the growth of SEI of more than 50nm is critically influencing the battery lifetime and performance.

The results demonstrate the formation of an SEI – which is comparable to SEIs in cells with liquid electrolytes – consisting of Li2S and Li3P and the formation of an overlayer consisting of lithium oxide. In situ XPS and impedance spectroscopy measurements show complementary results, as both reveal the formation of a slowly-growing SEI with a thickness of only a few nanometers.

Firstly, the synthesis of highly crystalline Li7P3S11 with very high ionic conductivity is reported. Secondly, we demonstrate by different methods that Li7P3S11 forms a non-growing resistive interphase in contact with lithium metal. Thirdly, using own XPS spectra of reference materials, a peak fit model for Li7P3S11 was developed, and we emphasize that this is the first XPS study of this material. The stability of Li7P3S11 in contact with lithium metal was then investigated by an in situ XPS technique, utilizing the developed peak model. The measurements clearly reveal the growth of an interfacial reaction zone (interphase) consisting of the decomposition products Li2S and Li3P. Both, in situ XPS measurements and time dependent impedance spectroscopy show the formation of a slowly growing interphase, comparable to a conventional SEI in cells based on non-aqueous liquid electrolytes. In ex situ XPS investigations only Li2S was found at the interphase, further XPS investigations on the stability of the interphase showed that Li3P decomposes easily. We conclude that Li3P is unstable in the glove box and UHV atmosphere. Coupled fits of XPS spectra revealed that the SEI shows a thickness of only a few nanometers, which fits well to values obtained by impedance spectroscopy. Additionally, depth profiling showed that Li7P3S11 is stable against soft sputter etching, as the starting material was completely recovered.

As already anticipated from the significant resistance increase measured by impedance spectroscopy, the formation of Li2S and the instability of Li3P at the interface degrade the interfacial properties (transfer resistance etc.) between solid electrolyte and metal anode. Thus, aiming at the potential application of Li7P3S11 in an all solid-state battery, thorough interface modification will be required to form a proper low-impedance interphase (or interface).
